data.title: How stable are clocks in network equipment
data.meta_description: Most high end network equipment (switches and routers) can act as a NTP-server for hosts in the network, but I cant find any information on how stable these are. Does anyone have any information or
data.text:
I have no clue about the internal clock stability, but it doesn't matter much since you absolutely want those devices to be be synchronized, i.e. be NTP clients of a trusted source.

This is the only way to ensure that logs (or snmp traps or whatever monitoring you use) are consistent among the devices, to allow a good interpretation.

Of course there should be no significant deviation between two NTP update. I have no real data about this but I never saw this problem arise with properly configured devices.

Clocks of network devices usually DO NOT have high-quality oscillators. Because those oscillators are expensive hardware.

If all you need is to distribute wall clock time through NTP (with millisecond precision) , they might suffice.

If you need high accuracy for services like TDM over packet, you will likely need either SyncE or PTP (precision time protocol), for sub-microsecond precision, and clock sources with high-accuracy oscillator (as you said, specific hardware).

The answer to your question depends on the level of accuracy which you need. For network logs and PCs/servers running normal applications, it is more than accurate enough. Very precise applications may require a dedicated GPS clock in the device.

The show ntp status command on Cisco devices gives you a lot of information.
